Anonymous Tue 12 Apr 2022 22:44:16 No.46892739 Report
Quoted By:
>>46892079
Frankly, I think this is kind of a weird opinion, given how the vast majority of modern Fantasy can trace its lineage back to LotR. But maybe that's just the thing: People have accepted that bedrock setting as part of the genre, so some resemblance is expected, rather than noted. But science fiction has a bunch of standard features that no-one would consider rip-offs. Just look at any generic sci-fi video game, and you'll see the wallpaper of the stereotypical science fiction setting. You can write novels upon novels about people hanging out on space ships without anyone batting an eye, for instance. Now, if they're also peaceful explorers from a future Earth that has solved all current day problems and banded together in a grand federation with other space-faring species... then things might start to look familiar.

*SPOILERS*
not him, but I wanted to write a war story similar to "have you seen the news", but I am afraid of making a direct copy of it down to the childhood friend, anthro/human relation, and the tragic separation and reunification. My greatest sin is wanting the anthro to be a rodent with whiskers and a cute tale, but also a tomboy like Krasna. I think canines/felines are overdone, but more obscure species are harder to write for me because their is no clear consensus on what and how they look like. I have read Firebrand, lightning in a bottle, and of course HYSTN, and I just have this kind of flow for writing childhood friend rodent girls and their sexy times. I have a clear grasp on how a intimate scene would go.

What oliver has written is a tale of a couple who love each other have a history, and it was all taken away. I think his story resonates so well due to how impersonal he keeps the conflict from the characters. We are never given an exact chronology of events or reasons why the war is happening, so all the violence is given without context to justify it, which I think makes it powerful. I wanted to replicate that feeling, but instead give more of a reasoning. I also loved the fanart merl did where they are sitting on the stairs at different places, to give a viewer a sense of time and nostalgia for a past that was a lot brighter that the current time.

I just can't shake the idea that I am going to copy Oliver's story, but I would love to replicate the feelings he gave the readers with it, without dwelling on it, specifically that art piece by merl, and that the fanart in the OP.

Anonymous Wed 13 Apr 2022 04:50:08 No.46900017 Report
Quoted By:
Ok, so I read Honda Nighthawk. First, let me say that I love the concept of it. It's a sweet little story of two lonely people connecting, and it made me feel good to read. The characters have enough in common that this interaction feels natural. Mark and Lucy are cute and I'd like to see you do more with them. Maybe you can do a follow up where they visit each other somewhere halfway between them. Or maybe Lucy runs away from home. What I'm trying to say is that I can't accept this ending as is and I demand more.
On to criticism:
The prose could use some work. At the beginning it feels very rigid and mechanical, and you have an issue maintaining the right verb tense.
>They get out, Mark watching his bikes get released and rolled down the ramp on to the dusty lot. It's a sober sight seeing something you've spent so much time, effort and money reduced to this. He really hoped he could get it fixed up, not just for the trip, but for the sake of the bike.
While we're talking about the narration, you went with a biased third person perspective. There's nothing wrong with that, but with that in mind you should try to moderate that bias.
>His hips buck and fidget instinctively as he finally reaches his peak her eyes going wide as she gets a mouthful of is his climax!
Exclamation marks generally don't fit with third person narration, especially not in a situation like this.
The sex scene itself feels kind of short, it's just shy of a thousand words. You can afford to flesh it out a little bit more, get into more nitty-gritty details. Erotica is supposed to be sensual.

Anonymous Wed 13 Apr 2022 09:32:29 No.46903480 Report
Quoted By: >>46903748 >>46904013
>>46898851
As several others said, breeding issues. I'd suggest going so far as no crossbreeding between species is possible. I mostly/usually favor this sort of universe because crossbreeding a human with a rabbit is absurd (for example). In a world with several anthro plus human species, in three generations none of the anthros would be recognizable. Therefore, if you like your particular anthro species, bloodlines have to remain within their genetic compatibility.

This doesn't mean that cross-species relationships are impossible, but there has to be a mechanism that allows for children. Could be pure social, or maybe scientific genetic manipulation, or whatever or whatever combination. But, the world has female humans in it, and they bear human children.

One mechanism is that cross-species relationships are fairly rare, for any of several reasons. Cross-species couples have to consider options other than directly breeding with each other. So adoption and forms of surrogacy, poly relationships, whatever you can imagine.

Just because our main character male in an /hmofa/ story likes anthros doesn't mean it's normal. He (and his love interest) could be deviants, outcasts by most other social norms. Inter-species relationships could be somewhat taboo, or maybe just distasteful.

I think too many of our stories are focused on it being all happy & easy & normal. Few of them focus on our couple being outcasts for their love.

Anonymous Wed 13 Apr 2022 11:00:54 No.46903958 Report
Quoted By: >>46904092
>>46903748
I didn't mean indistinguishable. I meant they would have all sorts of hybrid characteristics, as would humans. For someone into catgirls, for example, they might now come with cookies and antlers and a scaled fish tail. Some humans might have both dog faces and hooves, random individuals crotch tits. Etc.

The original question was world-building ideas. I've never liked crossbreeding and hybridization when it comes to anthros. I can see it between closely related species, such as leopards and lynxes. But some universes you start to get some truly weird and silly examples. As much as I like Sabrina Online, for example, it loses me when a squirrel and a wolf or a skunk and a racoon have hybridized offspring. Most of the worlds that allow that usually only explore a first generation mix. They tend to ignore what happens by the fifth generation. Even Star Trek managed to ignore that problem almost entirely.

A furry webcomic, https://www.tamberlanecomic.com/, actually does that. And you start to get some pretty weird and gross hybrids. Apart from stupid silly.

So back to world-building that encourages human females to be sexually competitive with various anthro options, I was suggesting the mechanism of no crossbreeding, and then combine it with various political/sociological/religious inhibitions and taboos on interspecies relationships. You then get a Zootopia-like society where species interact, but with limits, and you get species purity of genetic lines by the fundamental nature of the universe. An interspecies couple can still have a family, but they have to get creative about it. A sub-culture of society is comfortable with several species making up a family unit, but most of the rest of the world generally doesn't live that way. Some maybe very intolerantly so.
